title: Ticket #4090: Cleaner param_* interface
description:
Based on a discussion between knoeller and adesmet:

The current param_* system...

  • ...is error prone; if you typo the name, it will "work", but not as you expect.
  • ...requires passing in a default, which is redundant and potentially error prone for parameters in param_info.in.
  • ...has silly names. param_boolean returns a bool, not a boolean. param_integer returns an int, not an integer.
  • ...should remain valid C, so no function name overloading.

Proposed:

Add new functions. They should use the type actually returned (param_bool, param_int). They should not take a default. Instead of taking a typo-prone char*, it should take param_id, an enum from param_info_tables.h (the enum already exists, but is currently unnamed). Using the enum provides some type safety. If an out-of-range value is passed it, it should be a fatal error, as it represents either memory corruption or a serious programming error.

For example, where today we have 

  // These omit some specialized arguments
  bool param_boolean( const char *name, bool default_value);
  int param_integer( const char *name, int default_value = 0);

we would also have 

  bool param_bool(param_id id);
  int param_int(param_id id);

These new functions can't replace all cases, but they can replace a large number, probably the vast majority.
